subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Understanding, speaking, reading, and writing modern standard Arabic. Language laboratory.

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Continuation of Arabic 101. Prerequisite: Arabic 101 or equivalent.

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Continuation of Arabic 101. Prerequisite: Arabic 101 or equivalent.
instructors: Amal Boumaaza; Saad Cheikh Abdi ValL

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Targets intermediate level proficiency in Modern Standard Arabic though a communicative approach emphasizing daily life themes and essential grammatical structures. Assessment includes quizzes, writing, oral presentations, exams, and OPI. Active participation and a regular homework are crucial. Covers Chapters 14-20 in 'Al-Kitaab Fi Ta'allum Al-'arabiyya Part 1 (2nd edition) and supplementary material provided by the instructor. Recommended prerequisite: Arabic 102 or equivalent.
instructors: Badr Abdelfatta Badr; Saad Cheikh Abdi ValL

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: A mid-high intermediate course that focuses primarily on Modern Standard Arabic while also introducing an Arabic dialect of students' choice (Egyptian, Levantine or Moroccan) through media resources and the Aflaam site. Chapters 1-5 in 'Al-Kitaab Fii Ta'allum Al-'arabiyya Part 2' (2nd edition) are covered targeting mastery of grammatical concepts, such as verb tenses and participles while also expanding students' vocabulary. Assessment comprises quizzes, writing, oral presentations, mid-term a final exam, and an Oral Proficiency Interview in Arabic. Recommended prerequisite: Arabic 203 or equivalent.
instructors: Badr Abdelfatta Badr; Saad Cheikh Abdi ValL

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Readings in classical and contemporary fiction and nonfiction. Works include al-Jahiz, Ibn Arabi, Taha Husain, Ibn Battuta, Ghada al-Samman and 1001 Nights. Prerequisite: Arabic 204 or equivalent.

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Students will transition from reading short texts to completing a full novel, Sayyidi wa Habibi by Hoda Barakat. Focus on analyzing and discussing literary content. Students will strengthen their reading, writing, speaking, and comprehension skills. includes a service-learning component with native speakers. Recommended prerequisite: Arabic 305 or equivalent.

subject: ARABIC
catalog_description: Individual study of language for conducting research involving sources written or spoken in the language. Students have to submit a proposal describing the purported research, types of sources to be analyzed, and kinds of language knowledge or skills they need to be equipped with. Consent of instructor and director of undergraduate studies required.
